abstract.p: New York Liberty defeat Phoenix Mercury, 82-69 (S)

block.p: Liberty Coach Richie Adubato didn't need to offer excuses for his team's sputtering season. The Liberty began the defense of its Eastern Conference title without a stable center. A pivotal sixth player, Tamika Whitmore, was overweight and unable to play more than a few minutes without becoming winded. Then Crystal Robinson, the 3-point shooting ace, sprained her ankle.
But the Liberty made the most of a lackluster effort by the Phoenix Mercury to snap out of its funk last night with an impressive 82-69 victory before 13,054 fans at Madison Square Garden.

Liberty Coach Richie Adubato didn't need to offer excuses for his team's sputtering season. The Liberty began the defense of its Eastern Conference title without a stable center. A pivotal sixth player, Tamika Whitmore, was overweight and unable to play more than a few minutes without becoming winded. Then Crystal Robinson, the 3-point shooting ace, sprained her ankle.
But the Liberty made the most of a lackluster effort by the Phoenix Mercury to snap out of its funk last night with an impressive 82-69 victory before 13,054 fans at Madison Square Garden.
Robinson hit 4 of 6 3-point attempts to finish with 14 points to go with 7 rebounds.
But the night belonged to the Liberty's Tari Phillips, a 6-foot-1-inch power forward acquired in a trade with Portland. Phillips led all scorers with 22 points.

Phoenix whittled a 41-23 halftime lead down to 3 points, at 51-48, with 12 minutes 11 seconds remaining. Phillips seemed to take the challenge personally. She scored on a pass from Teresa Weatherspoon, hit an eight-foot jumper and followed that with a layup to give the Liberty a 63-56 lead with 7:21 remaining.

''Phillips admitted being nervous when the Liberty's lead was reduced to 3. Then I got angry,'' she said. ''I said I don't want to replay that scene because I knew how it felt after the game against Los Angeles, and I knew I didn't want to feel like that again.''
